# StereoSet

<small><em>Original: 2021.acl-long.416.json</em></small>

## 📊 Benchmark Details

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Name</strong></td><td>
StereoSet
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Overview</strong></td><td>
A large-scale natural English dataset to measure stereotypical biases in four domains: gender, profession, race, and religion.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Data Type</strong></td><td>
Natural language
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Domains</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Gender</li>
<li>Profession</li>
<li>Race</li>
<li>Religion</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Languages</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>English</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Similar Benchmarks</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>CrowS-Pairs</li>
<li>WEAT</li>
<li>SEAT</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Resources</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://stereoset.mit.edu">Resource</a></li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
</table>

## 🎯 Purpose and Intended Users

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Goal</strong></td><td>
To measure and quantify the stereotypical biases present in pretrained language models.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Target Audience</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Researchers</li>
<li>AI practitioners</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Tasks</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Analyzing biases in language models</li>
<li>Comparing models based on bias and language modeling ability</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Limitations</strong></td><td>
Does not mitigate bias.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Out of Scope Uses</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Training models on StereoSet</li>
<li>Bias mitigation strategies</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
</table>

## 💾 Data

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Source</strong></td><td>
Amazon Mechanical Turk
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Size</strong></td><td>
16,995 test instances
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Format</strong></td><td>
Triplet format consisting of target context and associated attributes
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Annotation</strong></td><td>
All instances validated by multiple crowdworkers
</td></tr>
</table>

## 🔬 Methodology

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Methods</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Intrasentence Context Association Test (CAT)</li>
<li>Intersentence Context Association Test (CAT)</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Metrics</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Language Modeling Score (lms)</li>
<li>Stereotype Score (ss)</li>
<li>Idealized CAT Score (icat)</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Calculation</strong></td><td>
Calculate the percentage of instances preferring meaningful over meaningless associations and stereotypical over anti-stereotypical associations.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Interpretation</strong></td><td>
Higher lms indicates better language modeling ability while lower ss indicates less stereotypical bias.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Baseline Results</strong></td><td>
None
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Validation</strong></td><td>
Crowdsourced validation by 5 validators classifying associations
</td></tr>
</table>

## ⚠️ Targeted Risks

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Risk Categories</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li>Bias in AI systems</li>
<li>Misuse of bias data</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Atlas Risks</strong></td><td>
<ul>
<li><strong>Fairness:</strong> Data bias, Output bias</li>
<li><strong>Societal Impact:</strong> Impact on cultural diversity, Impact on education: plagiarism</li>
</ul>
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Demographic Analysis</strong></td><td>
Crowdworkers were sourced from the USA.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Potential Harm</strong></td><td>
Promoting stereotypes and biases through model deployment.
</td></tr>
</table>

## 🔒 Ethical and Legal Considerations

<table>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Privacy And Anonymity</strong></td><td>
Not Applicable
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Data Licensing</strong></td><td>
Not Applicable
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Consent Procedures</strong></td><td>
All workers were informed that their work would be used for a scientific study.
</td></tr>
<tr><td width="20%" align="center"><strong>Compliance With Regulations</strong></td><td>
Workers were compensated at a minimum rate of $15 per hour, complying with AMT policies.
</td></tr>
</table>
